Allah further explains that all kinds of blessings were gifts that He gave to Solomon specifically. These blessings included a great kingdom, abundant wealth, and power that had never been given to anyone else. These blessings were bestowed upon him so that they would be used as they should be.

Allah emphasizes that these blessings were given to Solomon without accountability, because Solomon had been given the ability to control all kinds of these blessings.
text.40: Then Allah explains that in addition to the glory he has achieved in the world, which is so astonishing, he will be showered with even more pleasant gifts and a more noble position. Allah promises him that he will be included in the ranks of His servants who have a very close position to Allah, namely the position obtained by the messengers and prophets, a good place of return, which is the Garden of Na'im filled with all kinds of pleasures.
text.41:
Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (saw) to tell his people the story of Ayub (Job), who was very patient in facing life's trials and obedient to Allah. When facing a very heavy trial, he prayed to Allah and complained that his suffering be removed.

Some commentators mention that Ayub was a very wealthy prophet. He was a farmer and livestock breeder. In addition, he was also the leader of his people in a land located southeast of the Dead Sea. His land was located between the city of Adum and the Arabian desert, very fertile, irrigated by many springs. He lived between the time of Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Musa. Initially, he lived prosperously and happily, was very devout, and had many relatives. He was very pleased with the results of his efforts, as well as his wealth, family, and health. Allah then wanted to test his steadfastness by inflicting him with a very severe skin disease. His illness was so severe and he suffered for so long that his wealth was exhausted, and his family scattered to neighboring countries to seek a livelihood. In the midst of his suffering, he felt very tired and miserable. He felt that there was a devil disturbing his soul when worshiping Allah. Then he complained to Allah to be given guidance to free himself from the suffering and torment he was experiencing.

Allah says:

And (mention) Ayub, when he called to his Lord, "Indeed, adversity has touched me, and You are the Most Merciful of the merciful." (al-Anbiya'/21: 83)
text.42:
This verse explains that because of Job's obedience and patience in facing trials, Allah answered his prayer by commanding him to strike his foot on the ground. Then, from the earth, a cool spring gushed forth. Then Job was commanded to bathe and drink from that water. Instantly, Allah healed his illness as if he had never been sick before.

Then he gathered his family who had been scattered, and they were finally able to spread many descendants, as a mercy from Allah to him and to his descendants.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that Job's obedience and patience are a lesson for people of understanding and a guidance for all mankind that Allah's mercy is very close to those who always do good deeds. This is also an example that every struggle, although initially feels very tiring, but if done with full perseverance, surely all difficulties can be overcome, and victory can certainly be achieved. A valuable experience that can be learned from the story of Job is that one should not despair in seeking a way out in facing obstacles, until he finds a way to overcome those obstacles, by asking for guidance from Allah to be given an abundance of His hidayah (guidance).

Then Allah recounts the easing of the punishment for his wife that was given to Ayub. Allah commanded Ayub to take a bundle of grass and strike his wife with it. This striking with grass was sufficient as a replacement for the oath he had once sworn. The verses of the Qur'an do not mention why he swore the oath or what the oath was. Only a hadith mentions that he swore because his wife, named Rahmah, daughter of Ifraim, went out for some purpose and was late in returning. Ayub swore to strike her 100 times if he recovered. With the striking of a bundle of grass, he was considered to have fulfilled his oath, as a mercy for Ayub himself and for his wife who had served him well during his illness. With this mercy from Allah, Ayub was spared from breaking his oath.

At the end of the verse, Allah praises Ayub as His servant who was patient, good, and obedient. Patient in facing the trials given to him, both the trials that befell him, his wealth, and his family. He was included in the group of His servants who were good in character because he did not easily despair, and he placed his hopes in Allah. He was also His servant who was obedient, because of his persistence in striving for the commands of religion and protecting himself, his family, and his people from destruction.

Regarding Ayub's obedience, it can be known from a narration that when he encountered a trial, he said:

"O Allah, You are the One who takes and You are also the One who gives."

At the time of *mujanat* (whispered prayer), he also said:

"O my Lord, "You know very well that my tongue will not differ from my heart, my heart does not follow sight, the slaves I own will not mock me, I do not eat except together with orphans and I am not in a state of being full and clothed while beside me there is someone who is hungry or naked."
text.45:
Allah commanded His Messenger to narrate to his people the struggle of Prophet Ibrahim, and his son Isaac who was also appointed as a prophet, as well as his grandson Jacob who also attained the degree of prophethood.

They were servants of Allah renowned for their steadfastness and who achieved glory through their obedience to Allah. Because of their persistent struggle in upholding truth and destroying falsehood, they were endowed by Allah with the strength to possess extensive religious knowledge and the strength to lead their people to the path of light, far from error. They were also given the ability to perform deeds pleasing to Allah, which are beneficial for the interests of their people's lives in this world and their happiness in the Hereafter.

In this verse, there is a subtle hint for the polytheists that if they are unwilling to learn from this story, then they will certainly remain in error, and in the Hereafter they will experience a most terrifying suffering.
text.46:
In this verse, Allah explains that the reason those prophets achieved glory in both this world and the hereafter is because they maintained the purity of their souls and distanced themselves from blameworthy sins. Because their souls were cleansed from the blemishes of polytheism (shirk), they sincerely obeyed Allah's commands. Also, because they always avoided reprehensible actions, they were persistent in upholding truth and eliminating falsehood. Thus, high morals and noble characteristics were reflected in their souls, making them worthy of emulation.

All their activities, whether in the form of energy, wealth, or thought, were solely used for pure worship, with the aim of obtaining Allah's pleasure (rida) and upholding the word of Tawhid. With this foundation, they always warned their people about the eternal life of the hereafter. The temporary pleasures of this world should be used as a means to devote oneself to Allah, so that in the hereafter they will obtain unending bliss, which is prepared for servants who obtain His pleasure. While servants who are disbelieving and always wallowing in the errors of life will feel a very painful torment.
text.47:
In this verse, Allah affirms that His chosen servants, namely Ibrahim, Ishaq, and Yaqub, truly possessed pure souls. Not even a trace of blameworthy characteristics, such as envy and arrogance, was implied in their souls. Rather, praiseworthy qualities emanated from within them, serving as examples and good role models for their people.

The lesson that can be learned from this verse is that a pure soul and a sound mind are prerequisites that must be fulfilled by those who desire glory in both this world and the hereafter. A person with a pure soul and a sound mind will certainly see the signs of Allah's greatness that exist within themselves and in the heavens and the earth and all that is in them. Meanwhile, a person whose soul is defiled and whose mind is shackled by materialism will certainly not see the signs of Allah's greatness and will not see the truth of the revelation brought by the messenger.

This verse separates the mention of Ismail from his father, Ibrahim. This indicates a separation between the two. Indeed, Prophet Ismail separated from his father after he was left with his mother, Hajar, in Mecca. Thahir bin 'Asyur, as quoted by Quraish Shihab, understands that the separation is because Prophet Ismail would later become the ancestor of a great nation, namely the Arabs. Meanwhile, Ishak and Yakub are united with Ibrahim because they are indeed the ancestors of the Children of Israel (Bani Israil).

The grouping of Ilyasa' and Ismail is due to similarities between the two, including that they are both chosen people. Ilyasa's position among the Children of Israel is similar to Ismail's position among the descendants of Ibrahim. The similarity is that Ilyasa' helped Prophet Ilyas, just as Ismail helped Ibrahim.

According to asy-Syaukani in Tafsir Fath al-Qadir, it is mentioned that the grouping of the mention of Zulkifli, Ilyasa', and Ismail is because they have a similarity, namely that they are patient people.

At the end of the verse, Allah affirms that they are the best of Allah's servants, of high character, noble character, and guiding their people to obey Allah and avoid polytheism.

In this verse, it is explained that the angels and Iblis asked Allah after He informed the angels that He would create a human being from clay. Their statement concerned the benefit of the human being that Allah would create. This question is explained in Allah's word:

And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." They said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You?" He said, "Indeed, I know that which you do not know." (al-Baqarah/2: 30)

Regarding the creation of humans from clay, it is explained here that based on scientific studies, the material for human creation is soil, more precisely referred to in this verse as clay. The term "clay" is usually used to name soil particles with the smallest size, a diameter of less than 0.5 microns (= 1/2000 mm). The term "clay" is also commonly used to name the type of mineral that forms these smallest soil particles. Due to its small size, clay, when mixed with water, will be colloidal: it does not dissolve but is evenly dispersed and difficult to separate from the water. As a mineral, clay is a group of hydrated alumino-silicates with a layered structure. Because of its structure, clay particles have an electrical charge. Other properties of clay minerals are plasticity, but this plasticity disappears when heated to a certain temperature because the mineral structure changes. The traditional use of clay is based on its physical properties, including its ease of being shaped and hardening when heated, so it is commonly used as a material for making earthenware or pottery and ceramics. The modern use of clay is more based on its chemical-physical properties, generally used as a catalyst in chemical reactions. Because of its chemical-physical properties, clay is the part of the soil that is most likely to play a major role in the process of the formation of early life on earth, including the creation of humans (see also al-An'am/6: 2, Fathir/35: 11; al-hijr/15: 26-28-33; al-Mu'minun/23: 12, 14; ash-shaffat/37: 11).

Allah conveyed to the angels that when He had perfected the creation of man and breathed His spirit into his body, they were commanded to prostrate to Adam, as a sign of respect for him.

This verse explains one of the processes of Adam's creation, which is from clay. The angels prostrated to honor him, because they were obedient to Allah, except for Iblis. He refused to honor Adam, so he was among the creatures who were disobedient to Allah. Iblis's disobedience to the command to prostrate to Adam has been mentioned in His word:

And (remember) when We said to the angels, "Prostrate before Adam," and they prostrated, except for Iblis. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers. (al-Baqarah/2: 34)

text.75:
Allah said to Iblis, "O Iblis, what prevented you from prostrating in respect to Adam, a being I created Myself with My power? I Myself created Adam, not one of My creatures who created him. Why are you acting arrogant and haughty? Have you felt yourself to be higher and more honorable among the creatures I have created, so that you think you have the right and authority to do what you want?"

Iblis answered and gave the reason for his disobedience. He said that he was better than Adam because Allah created him from fire, while Adam was from clay. According to Iblis, fire is better than clay because the nature of fire is always to rise and clay is always below. In fact, the origin material cannot be used as an indicator of the glory of a creature. Glory depends on obedience and submission to Allah. The conversation above is mentioned in Allah's word:

(Allah) said, "What prevented you from prostrating when I commanded you?" (Iblis) said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire, and You created him from clay." (al-A'raf/7: 12)

text.77:
Because of Iblis' disobedience in refusing to obey Allah's command, Allah expelled Iblis from Paradise and made him a cursed creature. This curse remains in effect until the Day of Judgment, which is the day of recompense for all of mankind's deeds.

Allah says:

"(Allah) said, "Descend from Paradise, for it is not for you to be arrogant therein. So get out! Indeed, you are of the disgraced." (al-A'raf/7: 13)
text.78:

Allah says:

(Allah) said, "Then get down from it [Paradise], as it is not for you to be arrogant therein. So get out; indeed, you are of the debased." (al-A'raf/7: 13)
text.79: After becoming a cursed creature, Iblis pleaded to Allah, "My Lord, if You have made me a cursed creature of Yours and have distanced me from Your mercy, then I ask that my life be prolonged until the Day of Resurrection. Do not let me die as long as the world exists."
text.80:
Allah granted Iblis' request by allowing him to live until the appointed time, as Allah says:

(Iblis) said, "Reprieve me until the Day they are resurrected." (Allah) said, "Indeed, you are of those reprieved." (al-A'raf/7: 14-15)
text.81:

(Iblis) answered, "Grant me respite until the Day they are resurrected." (Allah) said, "Indeed, you are of those given respite." (al-A'raf/7: 14-15)
text.82: Furthermore, Iblis pleaded again, "O my Lord, by Your power and glory, grant me the opportunity to tempt and mislead mankind from Your path, by making them see the evil and sinful deeds they commit as good."
text.83: Furthermore, Iblis said, "Indeed, Your servants who are strong in faith, who are submissive and obedient to You, cannot be tempted and led astray by me. Only disbelievers like me and those who are weak in faith are likely to be led astray by me."
text.84:
Allah granted Iblis' request and said, "The truth is with Me. Indeed, the truth is what I say. I will surely fill Hell with you and your descendants who come later and who follow you in misguidance from among the descendants of Adam." Allah threatens those who make Satan their leaders and neglect Allah's commands that lead them to happiness in this world and the hereafter. Allah says:

"And surely I will lead them astray, and surely I will arouse in them [sinful] desires, and surely I will command them so they will slit the ears of cattle, and surely I will command them so they will alter the creation of Allah." And whoever takes Satan as an ally instead of Allah has certainly sustained a clear loss. (an-Nisa'/4:119)

text.86:
Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to convey to the polytheists that he did not expect, let alone ask for, any reward from them in return for the task of conveying the religion of Allah. The Messenger did not expect anything at all. Only Allah would give him his reward. People knew the Messenger very well, that he never fabricated or made up things that were not true.

From this verse, it is understood that believers should emulate what the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did, which is to always convey the religion of Allah to people, even if they only know a little. Imam Muslim narrated that Ibn Mas'ud said:

"O people, whoever among you acquires knowledge, then let him speak it. And whoever does not know, let him say, 'Allah Taala knows best.'" Allah Taala said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), "Qul ma'as 'alukum . . ." until the end of the verse."
text.87: Allah affirms that this Al-Qur'an contains guidance and instruction for both jinn and mankind. Anyone with a sound mind will certainly acknowledge its truth. The Al-Qur'an is a guide to the straight path and a distinguisher between what is right (haq) and what is wrong (batil).
text.88: At the end of this surah, Allah conveys to those who do not heed the call of the Messenger of Allah, that they will know after death whether their actions were wrong or right.
